I live at 90, Villiers Street, Walworth, and am a grocer—I bought a piano of Young after the March quarter—I saw it at his shop at Champion Hill—the name of Young was over the shop—I gave him 12l. for it—he showed me a piece of paper, and said the brokers had sued for rent—I understood the piano was not on hire from what he said to me—it was taken to my premises, and has been claimed by Mr. Walters—I have made some arrangement with him.

Cross-examined by Young. You called at my place on 26th March—I showed you that the broker had distrained on the piano for rent—I don't recollect you first asking me to advance you 12l.; you might have done so—I saw a man in possession there—I brought the 12l. with me, and saw the piano—you paid me the 12l., and I sent you the receipt in the morning.

JAMES FOX . I am clerk to Henry R. Condy, of Battersea, a white lead manufacturer—we had a travelling man named Toby—we supplied through him two quarterns of white lead, value 4l. 13s., to Frederick Young, of Champion Hill, and we received this receipt, signed "A. Young:" I received this postcard, signed "Frederick Young," request
ing the lead without fail on Monday—on 7th April I received this other order for five cwt. of lead, value 4l.—on the 10th a man came and fetched it, and gave this receipt, signed "A. Young."
Cross-examined by Young. We received this order through Toby, out traveller—he is not here; we are in search of him—this is not the only order of the kind that we received through him.
WILLIAM EASTER . I am carman to Mr. Condy—I delivered these goods at 5, Melbourne Grove.

Cross-examined by Young. I believe A. Young signed for them—I can
not remember you—I only saw you for two minutes.

GEORGE ALDRIDGE . I am manager to Howard and Co., drysalters, 143, New Kent Road—about four months ago we supplied goods to Frederick Young, of Melbourne Grove, to the amount of 3l. 6s. 6d.—Mr. Welsford is our traveller—our terms are cash on delivery—cash not being paid, on the following Saturday I called at the oil shop in Melbourne Grove—I saw some one; neither of the prisoners—that person made an appointment for the following week—I then saw the prisoner Young—I told him I came after the account, 3l. 6s. 6d.—he said Mr. Young was not in; he would be in next Saturday—I called then and saw the other person—he said Young was not in—I used some strong language, and the prisoner Young then came forward—he said "I am Mr. Young, what have you got to say?"—I said "You might have told me that in the first instance," and I believe I called him a swindler—he did not pay me—I left, and never got any money—while this transaction was going on Randall called at our place, gave me this card, (As before), and ordered some goods amounting to 10l. or 12l.—I asked for a reference, and he gave Mr. Young, of Champion Hill—I did not go there; I told Eandall that Young's reference was hardly good enough, and we did not deliver the goods—while I was at Champion Hill I saw Randall there—he was taking goods away in a small trap—I saw him there four or five times; he was taking away goods more than once.

Cross-examined by Randall. You told me you were manager to Mr. Smart—you did not say anything about terms; you simply gave me the order—I saw you taking away several descriptions of goods; several cwt. of soap for one thing, and a bag of dog biscuits—the soap was not wrapped up—I saw you loading other goods on other occasions, but I am not able to specify what.
Cross-examined by Young. Your order was given through our traveller—he is not here—I did not see the goods delivered.

SAMUEL QUINT . I live at 116, Manor Road, Brockley—I am owner of the shop, 3, Doveridge Terrace, Melbourne Grove, Champion Hill—I let that shop to the prisoner Young from 14th January—he said that he and his brother wished to go into business, that they had got very little money to start with, something about 30l.—I said I would do all I possibly could to assist them—I let them the shop with fixtures and stock—he signed this agreement "Frederick Young," at a rent of 50l. a year—he gave me 5l. in part payment and a promissory note for 25l. signed by the prisoner and Albert Stanley—Stanley came to my place as a reference, and gave his address as 408, Albert Road, Battersea Park Road—he said he knew both the Youngs and their parents, and he thought they were very honest, straightforward young chaps—he called with one of the Youngs—the quarter's rent became due in March—I got 10l. the day after by putting in the brokers, from what the police told me—I went and found they had gone and the door left open—they took away some of the fixtures worth 4l. or 5l., and the stock was all gone.
Cross-examined by Young. You took possession of the place about the middle of January—I put in a distress the day after the rent was due—I

believe it was your brother who called with Stanley—you and your brother were at the place together—I could not swear who took the key—I did not see the agreement signed—the solicitor saw you sign it—I did not see the promissory note signed—I saw you when you made the agree
ment.

ALFRED DAVIS . I am agent to Mr. Fletcher, who is landlord of 5, Honor Oak Terrace, Forest Hill—I let those premises to a man who gave the name of James Ward under this agreement (produced) at a rent of 26l. a year—to the best of my belief the prisoner Young is the person—he paid a deposit of 1l.—I did not get any rent—I distrained—I received this understanding in the name of Frederick Wood—I forgave him the rent and he took the goods.

Cross-examined by Young. It is a private house—I did not see the docu
ment signed—I kept the 1l. deposit when you gave up possession—3l. 5s. is owing.

SARAH BIGGS . I live, at 76, Abingdon Road, Kensington—I am the owner of 221, Shakespeare Road—on 17th June I let that house to the prisoner Rand all under this agreement (produced) at 28l. a year—it is a private house—I did not see Randall sign the agreement, the agent saw him—he referred me to Mr. Strange, who keeps a little oilshop at 113, Station Road, Forest Gate—I saw Randall write this: "Charles Randall, 7, Santley Street, Acre Lane, Brixton. Mr. Strange, 113, Station Road, Forest Gate"—he had the premises up to the time he was taken into custody—I was not able to get any rent—he gave up the keys to a young woman who called him father—he said he took the house for himself and wife.
Cross-examined by Randall. You owe me a quarter's rent and I wish you would pay me—I did not apply for any rent till the 29th, and there was no one there.

WILLIAM PREDDLE . I live at 165, Elm Park, Brixton Rise—my cousin, Mr. Preddle, is landlord of 74, Elm Park—in February last an old man came and took that house—he is not here—Randall afterwards came with him—the old man introduced him as his manager who he would put into the shop till his younger son could take it; that his son was employed by Mr. Young, of Champion Hill, and in the mean time Randall would take possession of the shop and manage it for him—the reference given by Smart was Mr. Young, of Melbourne Grove, and Mr. Randall, S, Oscar Terrace, Beckton Road—I communicated with those addresses and got these replies. (The one from Young stated that he had known Smart some years, that the son had been manager of his shop for some time and he had no doubt he would be a desirable tenant and able to pay the rent. The reply from Randall stated that Smart had been a tenant of his for some years, that he had always found him prompt in his payments, and that he would no doubt be a desirable and responsible tenant.) Upon receiving those references I agreed to let the shop, and Smart signed this agreement in Randall's presence—the place was never opened for business—I called the day after the rent was due and found the place shut up and the man gone—I had seen Randall there in the mean time, and occasionally I saw the old man there—I do not know Young—I saw a young person who was represented by the old man to be his son, but I have since understood him to be Young's brother.
ROBERT POLE . I live at 3, Barking Road, Plaistow—I am proprietor

of 8, Yaelm Terrace, Beckton Road—on 1st November I let that shop to a man named Stanley on this agreement at a rental of 3.5l.—Stanley took possession of the premises—the place was opened in a week, but he never opened them for business—I received references to F. Fry and F. Williams—I saw both the prisoners at the premises—I knew Randall by the name of Stanley; at least I never could get at his name—when I in
quired his name he said "Oh, call me anything you like, Jones, Robinson, or anything you like"—he said he was manager there for Stanley—I saw people come and deliver goods there, and they went away again almost directly in carpet bags, boxes, carts, &c., at different times—I saw Eandall there in company with Stanley many times—he and his daughter lived in the house and two women and a lodger—I got no rent or a half
penny for the fixtures—I put in a broker for the rent—there were some goods on the premises which were claimed by a man named Shaw, who took them away—he represented himself as a lodger—Randall claimed the rest of the goods—I offered to forgive him the rent if he would go; he refused to go—the goods were impounded—subsequently Randall moved them away—very nearly all my fixtures were cleared out, about 10l. worth—I never got a sixpence.

Cross-examined by Randall. Goods were sent there after the first time I saw you—I don't know what they were—the previous tenant owed rent and left me the fixtures to dispose of; they were my fixtures.

WILLIAM EAST . I live at Mary Street, Barking Road—I am agent to the landlord of 8, Oscar Terrace, Beckton Road—on 28th January last I let those premises to a Mr. Shaw at a weekly rental of 6s.—on 4th Feb. I received the rent—I continued to receive it—Shaw's young man occu
pied the premises—he left in September and I think went to live at Brixton—I think I have seen Eandall about the Beckton Road, but had no business with him.

STANLEY ROGERS (Policeman P 129). In February, March, April, and May I was taking care of 2, Melbourne Grove, Doverage Terrace, adjoin
ing the Railway Oil Stores—I had occasion to notice what was going on there, and kept observation on the premises—I have seen the two prisoners there, and also a brother of Frederick Young named Arthur, and an elderly man; I did not know his name—there was very little business in the shop—I saw goods arrive from time to time, and as they were brought by the vans they were taken direct to a stable at the rear of the premises, put into a cart with the name of Hardy on it, and taken away—I should say I have seen fifteen loads taken away, principally in the night time—one load of dog biscuits in sacks were taken away the same day they came—I have seen the prisoner Young in the house and his brothers, and also Eandall; he was always there—on 12th May at six in the morning some fixtures and furniture were taken away by Randall, assisted by Samuel Hardy—I traced those things to 5, Honor Oak Terrace, Forest Hill Road—I afterwards went to 221, Shakespeare Road, and there saw Randall and Mrs. Young—there is a warrant out against Arthur Young; I have tried to find him and cannot—I don't know what has become of him.

Cross-examined by Randall. I saw you packing the cart with goods, assisting to load—you went with the van on two occasions—I had some conversation with you on the morning of 12th May, when the van was
loaded with the fixtures—you went away with the van—you told me you were going to make a clean breast of it.

Cross-examined by Young. I never saw you when they were moving the fixtures—my wife sometimes dealt with you—I have never seen you and your brother out delivering goods in the neighbourhood; only when you were going away with a van load of goods—you had a barrow there—I never saw you delivering goods in that—I have seen the shop regu
larly opened and seen plenty of stock there and upstairs also, but it has not been there very long—I have not said that I never saw a shop look so well—I have seen barrels there—I don't know whether they were full or empty.
Re-examined. I have seen Young there on occasions when goods were removed—he has helped to take them away.

DANIEL MORGAN (Police Inspector X). I know the prisoner Young by the name of Thomas Shaw and Thomas Hawes—I know his father; he has gone by 100 names, but I believe his correct name is James Shaw—I know Randall; Charles Thomas Randall is his correct name—in February, 1876, he was living at 11, Goose Green, Dulwich, with Young and his father, old Shaw, and the other brother who is now wanted; they were then in the name of Shaw and Hawes, all living there together—Randall married Young's elder sister; I have the marriage certificate—I cannot find old Shaw or the brother; they have absconded.

Cross-examined by Young. I first knew you swindling with a man named Hall—you were at 37, Charles Street, Hatton Garden, in Feb
ruary, 1876, when I called there in respect of certain frauds when Frank Hall was arrested—I swear it was you—I did not take you into custody then, because you were only 17, and I thought your father was the prin
cipal person; he was arrested—I have not found you anywhere since.

CHARLES VINEY (Police Sergeant P). I received Young in custody on this charge—I read the warrant to him—he said "Oh, that is only a debt"—it was for Mr. Garnham's dog-biscuits—I said "Well, it may be, if it stood alone; there is the piano at Mr. Walter's, at Camberwell, a sewing machine in the Borough, and many others"—he made no reply to that—I said "There is the shop in Oglander Road, last year"—he said "I never was in Oglander Road"—I said "You were, and you had goods there, and went away, and took the fixtures, and never paid any rent"—he said "I never was there"—I had seen him there on several occasions last year, and two or three years ago in a shop in Victoria Road, Peckham, which was never opened—after Young's arrest I went to 221, Shakespeare Road, and there saw Randall—I told him I was a police officer, and had a warrant for his arrest for being concerned with Young in fraud at Champion Hill—he said "What name have you got on the warrant?"—I said "Stanley"—he said "My name is not Stanley; you have made a mistake"—I said "Well, there is very little in names; you will have to go with me; there is the shop at Elm Park, Brixton, where you; were"—his daughter said, in his presence, "I had to do with all at Elm Park; I took in all that came there; my father knew nothing about it"—he said "I was only acting as manager there"—Young was by the name of Shaw at Victoria Road, and Sadler at Oglander Road.
Cross-examined by Young. The name of Wright was over the door at Oglander Road; he went away prior to your taking it—I saw you in the shop—your father no doubt took the shop, and you went there

as manager—you took the shop in Victoria Road of a man named Thorn
ton—I swear I saw you there.

p.hi: Young in his defence stated that he and his brother took the shops jointly; that they quarrelled, and his brother, unknown to him, cleared everything out; that he had no intention to defraud any one, and the cases against him were properly cases for the County Court, and not for a criminal one; Randall alleged that he only acted as a servant occasionally employed, and that there was nothing to show that he was connected with any conspiracy, or with the obtaining of any goods.

div1.p:
GUILTY .—
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour each.

74.
MARY ROONEY (69)
, Feloniously forging and uttering a receipt for 5l., with intent to defraud.

MARY ANN FARRELL . I am a widow, of 149, Snows Fields—the prisoner lives at 86, Paradise Street, Rotherhithe—about 12 months ago I paid 20l. into the post-office at Blackman Street, and got this book (produced)—I had drawn out all but 5l., and last February I went to draw that out, the prisoner was with me, and for some reason I could not get the money that day—the prisoner went home with me—she is in the habit of running in and out of my place, and she said "Lend me that book to show to my lodger"—that was Mrs. Keeling—two days afterwards the prisoner said to me "I have got the money out"—I did not believe it, but she noticed it in her hand—I had not given her authority to take it out, or to sign my name, or to produce my book—some long time afterwards the prisoner said "There is your book"—the signature in it is not in my writing; I can't write—I went and spoke to the postmaster, and then told the prisoner I found she had drawn the money out—she told me to summons her—I said "No, I will go where I put my money"—she then said "You won't get your money there"—when I asked her how she got it she said "They knew me, I live near."

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. Mrs. Keeling is a stranger to me—I don't know that she owed you 12l. for rent—when I went with you to the post-office you asked a lady there to sign the order for me, but that was torn up.
FRANCES KEELING . I am the wife of Thomas Keeling—I never had a talk with Mrs. Farrell about lending her 5l.

ANNIE CORBY . My husband is a cheesemonger—I was in Mrs. Farrell's shop when the prisoner came in and asked her how she got on; she said "Very badly indeed; I could do very well if I had that 5l. which you have so fraudulently taken from the post-office"—the prisoner said "Don't go to them or I shall not pay you; if you go to the post-office they will prosecute me, and then you will not be paid by anybody, I will not give you a farthing"—on 23rd August she came again while I was there, and said "Mrs. Farrell, I have got good news for you, I am going to get a loan and pay you the money; live you been to the post-office?" she said "No, I have been very ill, but I shall go"—she said "Don't; if you go they will prosecute me, and then I shall not pay you a farthing"—she showed me her book, and I expected to hear that her money had been drawn out; up to that time she was not quite sure.

ALEXANDER HORNE . I am a carpenter, of 52, Long Lane, Borough—the prisoner came to me and asked me to fill up this form to the post-master and sign it for Mrs. Farrell for 5l., as Mrs. Farrell was ill and

unable to come—a few days afterwards she brought me this other form to the postmaster, "Pay Mary Ann Farrell 5l."—I did not sign "Mary Ann Farrell," but I witnessed the mark—I never saw Mrs. Farrell from beginning to end—I went with the prisoner to the post-office and saw her produce the order and get the money, and she gave me 2d. for a glass of ale.

EMMA WATKINS . My husband is a boot and shoe maker, of 38, Tooley Street—the prisoner rented two rooms in our house, and early this year she owed me 2l. 8s. for rent—I asked her for it, and she said "I am going to the post-office to get some money"—she went next door to Mr. Thorne and she and I and Mr. Thorne went to the post-office together—I saw Mr. Thorne write something on a paper and the prisoner took up a pen and put a cross to it, handed it to the postmaster, and got the money.

EMILY GORDON . I am a clerk in the General Post-office—on 14th February I received this notice to withdraw and sent this order to pay, addressed, "Mary Ann Ford, 29, College Street, Tooley Street," by post.

HARRIET TRIBE . I am a clerk at the District Post-office, Blackman Street, Borough—this warrant to pay was brought to me, the address is in my writing—it is always a practice to put the cross in my presence—I paid the money.
GEORGE HARVEY (Police Sergeant M). I charged the prisoner on 6th October—she made no reply at the time—2l. 17s. 7 1/4 d. was found on her—she then said "Oh, it is by the will of God I am here."

p.hi: The prisoner in, her statement before the Magistrate and in her defence said that Mrs. Farrell had been robbing her for six months, and this does done through spite.

div1.p: MARY ANN FARRELL (Re-examined). That is not true—I asked her to give me some of the money to pay the rent, she has never paid me a farthing—I worked for her for six months after I got it back, and never had a farthing—I had a child to keep and I am destitute, I have nothing left but a bedstead—the Magistrate gave me money to get my child provided for—the prisoner sent her son to represent me as dead when she got a loan, she has let me starve.

GUILTY .*—
Fifteen Months' Hard Labour.

75.
JOHN GEORGE FORGE (33)
PLEADED GUILTY to two indict
ments for feloniously forging and uttering endorsements to two orders for money, with intent to defraud.—
Nine Months' Hard Labour.

76.
WIL
LIAM STOKER (18)
to unlawfully obtaining 4l. 3s. 5d. of
Robert Haines by false pretences.—
Six Months' Hard Labour. And
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

77.
GEORGE JOHN
SON (21)
to stealing 6s. 9d. from the person of
William Hickley;
also to stealing 6s. 6d. and a latch key from the person of
Charles Mason.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

78.
WILLIAM JONES (20)
, Robbery with violence on
John Crawley, and stealing a watch and chain, his property.
MR. PELLEW Prosecuted; MR. BLACKWELL Defended.

JOHN CRAWLEY . I am a labourer, of 6, Earl's Place, Queen Elizabeth Street—I am a cripple—on 25th October, at 8 p.m., I was in the Wallace public-house, Borough—I felt unwell, went out, and saw the prisoner there—I had seen him before—I went in—I asked him to direct me—

we went through an archway near the bridge—he said "Here you are all right," and he and a man not in custody sprang upon me, laid me down, and nearly choked me—they unbuttoned my coat—the other man held me by my throat, and the prisoner took my watch—they went towards the Borough Market, and I got up and told a constable—I saw the prisoner next day by the same public-house, and went and told a constable, and when I returned he was gone—I saw him again an hour after at a whelk-stall, and when I made a noise with my crutch he walked into a public-house—a policeman fetched him out, and I charged him with stealing my watch—he said I had made a mistake, but I am sure he is the man—he was remanded for a week, during which I came home on a Thursday, and found my watch there—it is worth 12s.

Cross-examined. The policeman said I was under the influence of drink, because I stumbled over a carpet—my carman and I had had one or two pints—I never told any one that I thought the prisoner was the man, though I saw a fellow very much like him on the same night, selling boxes in the London Bridge Tavern, and I made a report at the police-station—he said "Don't you know me?"—I said "You look like the man I am looking after"—I did not say "I have just lost my watch and chain, and I think you have it"—he did not say "Do you think I have got it?" nor did I say "I don't know, but you are very much like the party; had I not seen you with those goods you are selling I should have given you in charge." (A man named Brindsley was here brought into Court), that man was with him; they were selling boxes together—I have not said that I would not appear if the prisoner's friends gave me 10s.; but two fellow, strangers to me, came up, and said "If we give you 30s., and send your watch back, will you take no notice? we know where it is"—I said "Send the watch back first"—I did not send word to the prisoner's mother, I did not know where she lived, but she came crying to the police-court on the 27th, and offered me money.

BENJAMIN POLLEN (Policeman). I was on duty on London Bridge on 26th Oct., and at 9.45 p.m. Crawley spoke to me, he was called away by another man, he went to the London Bridge Tavern and returned, we then went to a public-house, and the prisoner was there drinking with other men, and before Crawley gave him in custody some of the men said, "That is not him," he was afterwards pointed out to me and I took him in custody—he said, "I am innocent, I can prove where I was; I was at the music hall till twelve;" but before the Magistrate he said, "I did not say so, I said that I was at the Drummond public-house, Snowsfields, from eight till twelve."
Cross-examined. I made no note of the conversation—I did not think it necessary.
Re-examined. I received the watch from Crawley on the 30th, at a little before nine o'clock.

JOHN PENNY (Policeman). On 25th October, at 7.30 p.m., I was on duty under the dry Arch of London Bridge—I saw the prisoner and Crawley—as they passed the prisoner said, "It is all right, governor"—I made no reply and they passed on; Crawley came back in ten minutes and complained to me, I referred him to the station—on Monday I went to the station and picked out the prisoner from nine other men—I had seen him before, and have no doubt he is the man—Crawley was the worse for drink.

WILLIAM BESLEY (Policeman M 98). On 25th Ootober I was on duty at London Bridge Tavern about 7.15 p.m., and saw the prisoner outside—about a quarter of an hour after that Crawley came and complained to me—I am sure the prisoner is the man.

EDWARD CARPENTER . I am landlord of Drummond's public-house, Snow Street—on 3rd November I saw the prisoner at the police-court—I had never seen him before—if he had come to my house on Saturday, October 25th, I must have seen him, and should have known him.

Cross-examined. There were between forty and fifty people in my house between eight and twelve on October 25th, popping in and out—a young man was lying dead there, and there was an entertainment there to raise money for him—I have not told Mrs. Stanton that I could not be sure whether he was there or not—I said that I did not see the prisoner, but that people may have popped in and out.
Re-examined. I might not have noticed people who popped in and out, but if anybody had stopped there from eight till twelve I must have noticed them.

He then
PLEADED GUILTY†to a conviction at Southwark Police-court, in February, 1884.—
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

79.
GEORGE SMITH (22)
, Robbery with violence on
Ellen Carter, and stealing a chain, a locket, and a trinket, her property.

ELLEN CARTER . My husband keeps a coffee-house at 40, New Kent Road—on 5th Ootober, about 9.20, I was opposite St. George's Church in the Borough, waiting for an omnibus, and the prisoner rushed upon me, tore my mantle down, and got my gold chain, which was under it, and a gold pencil case, locket, and pen on it—he had a cap with a peak to it—he rushed up a court towards the back of the Mint—I went to the station and made a complaint—I picked him out at the station among eight others on 16th October; he asked me if I was sore of him, I said "Yes, I believe you are the man"—I can now swear he is the man—the articles were worth about 11l.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. You were the only man with a cap; all the others had hats.

THOMAS PICKLES (Police Sergeant M). On 16th October, about eight p.m., I saw the prisoner at the corner of Mint Street, and said "I shall take you to the station for identification"—he said "What for?"—I said "I will tell you when we get to the station"—when the charge was read he said nothing—he was placed with eight others, and Mrs. Carter pointed to him directly, and said "I believe that is the man"—he said "I am innocent"—he said to Mrs. Carter "I believe you said just now that you believed I was the man?"—she said "Yes, I do believe so"—he gave his address at Godding's lodging-house, Red Cross Street, which was correct—he said next day before the Magistrate that he was in bed at nine o'clock on the night of the robbery.
Cross-examined. I was talking to you about eight p.m. on the Monday—I did not arrest you then because I had not then seen the prosecutrix.
Prisoner's Defence. I was in bed at nine o'clock; she said at first that
it was done at nine o'clock, and now she says twenty minutes past nine. I am innocent.

He then
PLEADED GUILTY** to a conviction of housebreaking in 1881.—
Five Years' Penal Servitude.

80.
EMILY BUDD (42)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

WILLIAM HUBBARD . I keep the Surrey Arms public-house, Wilcox Road, Lambeth—on 18th October, about half-past eleven a.m., I was serving, when the prisoner came in for a pint of four ale, and tendered a half-crown—I gave her 2s. 4d. change, and then tested the half-crown in my teeth, which sank into it—I told her it was bad, and asked where she got it—she said at a butcher's on the terrace—I said "What butcher's?"—she said "From Mr. Reed, or one of the other butchers"—she then gave me a good shilling, and gave me back my change, and I returned her the half-crown—I was quite sure it was bad, and quite sure she was the woman—I did nothing besides biting it; two or three of my customers handled it, and some of them followed her—she would not let them damage it in any way because she said she wanted to take it back.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I sent one of my customers to see where you went, and you went to 7, Luscombe Street.

CHARLES LANGLEY . I am a butcher, of 3, Simpson Street, Wands
worth Road—on the morning of 22nd October, between eleven and twelve, the prisoner came to my stall in the Wandsworth Road and asked for a pound of 4 1/2 d. pieces, and tendered a half-crown—I gave her 2s. 1 1/2 d. change, and she went away—I put the half-crown in my pocket—I had no other half-crown there—I looked at it again when I got home, and found it was bad—I put it in the tester and it broke—I put the smallest piece in the fire, and this other piece (produced) I gave the sergeant—I am quite certain the prisoner is the woman.

ALFRED VAUGHAN . I am a butcher, of 281, Wandsworth Road—on 24th October, about 5.30 in the afternoon, the prisoner came to my stall for half a pound of 4 1/2 d. pieces and tendered this half-crown—I gave her two separate shillings and 1 1/2 d. change and put the half-crown in a jug where there were only coppers—about half an hour after Langley com
municated with me, and I then examined the half-crown and found it was bad by indenting it with my teeth—I work at Charles Langley's stall—on 25th October, the next morning, I and Mr. Hubbard saw the prisoner in the Luscombe Road outside a public-house, I recognised her and gave her into the custody of Detective Vagg—I had no conversation with her, the constable had.

ALFRED BEACH (Policeman W 52). On 25th October the two last witnesses gave the prisoner into my charge for uttering two counterfeit half-crowns on 22nd and 24th October—I said "You will be charged with uttering two counterfeit half-crowns"—she said "I wasn't there, I know nothing about it, I am a respectable married woman"—I took her to the station and she was charged, I was not then present.

AUGUSTUS LABAN . I live at 21, Orris Street, Wandsworth, and am an engineer—on 18th October I was in the Surrey Arms when the prisoner came in for a pint of ale and put down a half-crown, which Mr. Hubbard afterwards passed round the company in the house—I examined it, I
thought it was bad—I put it in my mouth and left teeth marks in it—I am perfectly sure the prisoner is the woman that came in.

WALTER VAGG (Detective W). I was at the police-station when the prisoner was brought in on 25th October charged by Vaughan and Hubbard with uttering a half-crown to Vaughan and also one to Langley—replied (I took it down at the time) "Well, I was never in the parish, I was never here, I was never out of my home; it is very cruel to bring me here I do not know what a bad half-crown is, I am wrongly here; I am the wrong person, go and bring in the right person, what you are paid to do"—4d. good Money was found on her—she gave the address, 20, Britannia Place, Bow Lane, Battersea—that is about two and a quarter miles from the Wandsworth Road.

WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . This half-crown and a very large portion of another one are both bad, not from the same mould—the teeth generally sink into and make a groove in a bad coin—that is observable on one of these, not much on the-other—you could not do that to a good coin your teeth would come on that as on glass.
The Prisoner's Statement before the Magistrate. "I know nothing of it. I am quite innocent of it. I was at home turning the mangle."

MARY ANN BENNETT . My husband is an engineer's fitter—on 24th October I went into the prisoner's place at 5 o'clock to ask her if she could lend me 1s. to get my children some tea, and at a quarter-past 5 she lent it me, when her son home came from Price's factory—at a quarter-past 6 she lent my son 4d. to pay his fare to Vauxhall—at a quarter-past 8 I paid her back the shilling I had borrowed.

Cross-examined. I then lived next door to the prisoner—I might have been two or three minutes after a quarter-past 5—I fix the time by the time her son comes home from Price's, he gets paid at 5 and has five or six minutes' walk from there.

By the COURT. I believe she was at home between a auarter-past 5 and 6—I cannot say she was in and out of my place, but I dont think she was out of the place till after 8—I saw her at different times in my place.

JANE LEGG . I am William Legg's wife—we live at 14, Britannia Place, Battersea, in the same street as Mrs. Bennett—I was in her house on 24th October when the prisoner came in and lent Mrs. Bennett some money a little after five, and at 6 o'clock I was there when she lent Mrs. Bennett's son 4d.—I was there the whole time, because my little boy was not well, and I was sitting up with it; the prisoner was not there the whole time; she was in and out—she was back at 8 and was paid back again—I know the prisoner through her doing my mangling.

Cross-examined. I saw the prisoner in Mrs. Bennett's house three or four times between 5 and 6, but she did not stop long—I was there nursing my little boy, whom I had taken over to show Mrs. Bennett—I know it was a little after 5 because I have to get my husband's tea at 6, and I got it ready an hour before I went over.

HOLLOWAY. I am a fishmonger and general dealer, of 39, Britannia Place, Battersea—on Friday evening, 24th October about thirty-five minutes to 6, I served the prisoner with some fish—at a quarter to eight she came for some more, and wanted particularly a large one for her husband to take to his work in the morning—I know her husband.
Cross-examined. The prisoner is a customer of mine and does our

mangling very often—I can fix the time because I had been to Price's candle factory—I left there at 25 minutes past 5, and when I opened my door it was half-past 5 by St. Peter's Church opposite my house, and the prisoner came in about five minutes afterwards—I did not go to the police-court because I was not asked—her husband came and asked me if she had been in—I mentioned the hour first to him.

MATTHEW CHARLES BENNETT . I am a labourer of 111, Livingstone Road, near Clapham Junction, Battersea—on 24th October, about 6 o'clock, I was at 19, Britannia Place, where I borrowed 4d. of the prisoner to pay my fare to Lambeth—I am Mrs. Bennett's son.

JOHN BUDD . I am the prisoner's son—on 24th October I came home with my money at 5 o'clock from Price's candle factory, where I work—the prisoner was at home then, and I saw her there nearly all the evening till I went out at 5.55 or 5.50.

ANNIE CHAPPLE . My husband is an engineer—we live at 7, Luscombe Street, Wandsworth Road—on Wednesday, 22nd October, I was at my sister's, the prisoner's, house, from 11 o'clock till my husband came home to tea about 5.30 or 6—I go by the tram to my sister's; it is a twopenny fare—it might have been a little before 11 when I went; I generally go about that time.

Cross-examined. I go there once or twice a week—I wash and take my little girl to school, and then go—I left home about 9.30, and called on a friend, and got to her about 11—I did not notice the time I got there—I do a little needlework for my sister—she was at home, and made me a cup of tea—she very rarely comes down to me—she has a large family of children—I have lived in the Wandsworth Road for two years, near this butcher's—I have known Langley eight or 10 years—I was in the same shop as he was.
Witness recalled in Reply:—

ALFRED VAUGHAN . On 24th October the prisoner came to my stall about 5.30—I fix the time because the men were just coming out of the works opposite my stall—on 25th October I saw her in Luscombe Street, and communicated with the constable—I had never seen the prisoner before—I don't know Mrs. Chapple.

p.hi: The prisoner in her defence contended that it was a case of mistaken identity and that she knew nothing about it.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

81.
LEONARD COLLINSON (21)
PLEADED GUILTY to obtaining a quantity of silk and tea by false pretences, with intent to defraud.—
Judgment respited to next Sessions.

82.
JOHN EDWARDS (19)
to burg
lary in the dwelling-house of
William Maries, and stealing a coat, also to a previous conviction of felony in September, 1883, in the name of
John Pepiot.—
Two Years' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

83.
ARTHUR O'CONNOR (28)
to stealing a tricycle, also* to a previous conviction of felony in November, 1883, at Leeds, in the name of
Harry O'Day. The constable stated he held three other warrants for his arrest.—
Two Years' Hard Labour. And
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

84.
RICHARD BARRON (38) and
JOSEPH O'NEIL (20)
to attempting to commit an abominable offence.—
Judgment respited. [Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

85.
CHARLES HARRIS (18)
was, indicted for, and charged on the Coroner's Inquisition with, the wilful murder of
Arthur Arnold.
MESSRS. POLAND and MONTAGU WILLIAMS Prosecuted; Mr. PURCELL
Defended at the request of the COURT.

GEORGE NASH . I Live at 8, Clarendon Street, and am a labourer—on Sunday, 21st September, about half-past 12 o'clock in the morning, I was with a man named Murphy and Arnold at the top of Clarendon Street—we all three went to a coffee stall at the top of Bermondsey New Road; we met on the road Harris, William Piggott, Margaret Good
son, and Annie Keefe—I did not know her, but I knew Goodson—Goodson said to me "What cheer, Punch?"—I said "What cheer, Mog?"—Harris immediately after that came round and struck me in the jaw—I said "What did you do that for?"—he then hit me again, and said, "What did you want to kick her for?"—I had not touched her—I hit him and knocked him against the shutters—Arnold then held me back and said "I am more his equal than you"—I got away from Arnold and struck Harris in the face—he then went to the shutters and pulled some
thing from underneath the left breast of his coat and struck me in the back—I then found that I was stabbed—Harris then ran away and Arnold after him—I was taken to the hospital; when I got there I found that Arnold was there—he was wounded also.

Cross-examined. When I and Arnold came up the two girls were talk
ing to the prisoner—I heard the prisoner say "What did you want to kick her for?"—I did not hear him say "Don't interfere with these girls"—Arnold did not strike the prisoner in the face and make his nose bleed, nor did he knock him down—I did not knock him down, I am quite certain of it—he did not say while on the ground "Let me get up; oh, they are killing me."
Re-examined. I picked up a hat afterwards in the crowd—I gave it to Constable P 267.

JOHN MURPHY . I am a labourer, living at Tabard Street—on the night of 20th September I was with Nash at a friendly meeting, and about 20 minutes past 12 we went to the top of Clarendon Street, and there met Arnold—we all three then went along to Old Kent Road to a coffee stall—we met Harris with two or three women—Nash spoke to the girls and said "Halloa, Mog"—with that Harris struck him in the jaw and said "What did you kick her for?"—with that Harris stepped back and Nash ran towards him—I stood on the causeway and saw Harris running along by the shirt shop as if trying to get away from Nash—he fell back towards the shops—Arnold ran after him, and I ran towards him to see what was the matter—I saw Arnold stagger back, and he said "I am stabbed"—he then fell—I ran after Harris—a gentleman threw Nash's coat across my shoulders and threw his hat on the ground—I ran after Harris down towards Tabard Street—he was taken into custody as he was walking up from Falstaff Yard, and I and the constable and Harris went to the station—I was sober and so was Nash and Arnold.

Cross-examined. When Harris fell back against the shop Nash was near him; Arnold was at a distance from him—I cannot say whether Nash struck Harris; I saw he was bleeding when he came up from Falstaff Yard—I never saw Arnold have hold of Harris—Arnold fell back, and then Harris ran—I did not hear any one say "Let me get up; they are killing me"—there were a lot of men round Harris; I wild not see what was going on inside the crowd.

MARGARET GOODMAN . I live at 61, Little Surrey Street—on Sunday morning, 21st September, I was with Annie Keefe and Elizabeth Pace in the Old Kent Road—I saw the prisoner outside the undertaker's, Knox's—I had not known him before—I spoke to him, and immediately Piggott and John Harris came up, and we were talking together—Nash and Arnold then came along; one of the two made a kick at the girls, but neither of us caught it—the prisoner asked who they were interfering with—I did not hear any one answer—I saw one of them strike him on the nose; it was the youngest of the two that did it—it made his mouth and nose bleed—the prisoner then returned the blow, and then they both began hitting one another—the second one then interfered, and the three fell to the ground in the struggle—while on the ground I heard Nash call out that he and his mate had been stabbed—Nash got up and fell against the wall—I went up to him, and found that he was wounded behind—I did not see what became of Arnold—I had known Nash by sight before, but I did not know the others—when I saw this I went away home; I was sober.
Cross-examined. I was separated from Annie Keefe when the crowd came.

ANNIE KEEFE . I live at Kent Cottages, Lovegrove Street, Old Kent Road, and am a laundry woman—about half-past twelve on this Sunday morning I was with Margaret Goodson and Elizabeth Pace going along the Old Kent Road—we met the prisoner, and while we were talking a man named Piggott came up, and soon after Nash and Arnold came up—I had not seen them before, nor Harris, but I knew Piggott—Nash and Arnold pushed up against us—there was another man with them, who I believe was Murphy—Arnold made a kick at one of us; it did not touch us—the prisoner then turned round and said "Don't interfere with these girls, they did not interfere with you"—Arnold then turned round and struck the prisoner in the face, causing his nose to bleed—the prisoner then turned round and struck him a blow in the face—they then struggled together and fell, and while struggling a lot of fellows came up Great Weston Street, and said to Piggott "Come on, let us have his lot," and they knocked Piggott down and kicked him—I don't know any of the chaps—while the three were struggling I saw the prisoner make a blow at Nash—I did not see what was in his hand; I thought it was his hand—I saw no more, and after I heard that the deceased was stabbed I saw Arnold lying on the ground; I don't know how he came there—I heard that Harris had run off, but I did not see him run—I afterwards saw Nash and Arnold taken in cabs to the hospital, and I saw Piggott brought back by a policeman, and I went home.

Cross-examined. I don't remember after Arnold struck the prisoner on the nose and he returned the blow his moving back a few yards—Arnold and Nash knocked him down and kicked him, and also knocked down Piggott and kicked him—the prisoner then said "Let us get up; oh, they are killing me"—I saw them kick him—the prisoner asked to be allowed to get up and he would fight them one at a time; they would not let him get up—Nash had got hold of the prisoner when Arnold and Harris were struggling together.
WILLIAM STOCKS . I live at 34, Alfreton Street, Old Kent Road—I am a potman—about 20 minutes past 12 o'clock on 21st September I was doing home along the Old Kent Road, and saw Harris and some women,

and Nash and Arnold—I heard Harris say "I will do for you, you b——" that was to Arnold—a wrestle then took place, and I heard Arnold say "I am stabbed"—I ran to fetch a policeman, and in about five minutes I came back and Arnold was took to the hospital—I saw Nash standing by a lamp-post—there was a cab standing there, and I put him into the cab to go to the hospital.
Cross-examined. A crowd was round the prisoner when he used the expression—Arnold and the prisoner were struggling together, and Arnold fell to the ground—I did not see Nash on the ground.

THOMAS HANSON . I am a plasterer at 134, Weston Street, Ber
mondsey—about a quarter past 12 on Sunday morning, 21st September, I was going along the Old Kent Road—I saw a crowd and saw Nash and Harris struggling—I saw Harris run away and heard Nash say "I am stabbed"—I saw Arnold standing about ten yards off, bleeding from the thigh—I fetched a constable and a cab and went with him to the hospital—I afterwards saw Harris in custody.

THOMAS HAYNES (Policeman P 267). On Sunday morning, 21st Sept., about a quarter past 1, I was on duty in the Old Kent Road—Hanson came to me; in consequence of what he said I went across the road and saw Arnold insensible in the arms of two men, bleeding very profusely from the left thigh—I saw blood on the pavement—I at once got a cab, and with assistance lifted him in and took him to Guy's Hospital—Nash was also brought there in a cab; he had been stabbed—I saw a mark on his back—Nash handed me a hat—I afterwards saw the prisoner at the station without a hat—he was apparently shamming drunkenness—I tried the hat on him; he said it was his—on 3rd October I was outside his cell while Ferris was examining him to see if there were any marks on his arm, and I heard the prisoner say "I would like to serve you, you b—, the same as I served the other two, and would if I had the same tools"—when I first saw him at the station there were some marks of blood and mud on his face.
Cross-examined. We were not talking to him when he said this; I was standing outside talking to a witness—he appeared to be serious when he said it.

JOHN FERRIS (Policeman M 136). About 1 in the morning of Sunday, 21st September, I was on duty in Tabard Street, Old Kent Road—in consequence of what some men said to me I went down Falstaff Yard—when I got halfway down I saw the prisoner there without a hat, bleed
ing from the nose and mouth—somebody called out "That is the man that stabbed two men"—I told the prisoner I should take him into custody on that charge—he said "All right, master, but look at the way I have been knocked about"—as I was taking him to the station some man gave me this carving knife—there was no blood on the blade; there was just a slight stain on the handle—at the station I searched the prisoner, and found on him this clasp knife—there were fresh blood stains on the top of the blade, and about an inch and a half down—it was shut when I took it from him—on 8th October, in consequence of what occurred before the Magistrate, I examined the prisoner in the cell passage to see if I could find any marks upon him—there were none—while I was doing it he said "I would like to serve you the same, you b——, as I served the other two, and would, if I had the same tools."
CHARLES CONNOR . I am a hawker, and live at 7, Eltham-Street,

Borough—on Sunday, 21st September, about 12.50, I heard something, and went with some men and looked behind some barrows in Falstaff Yard, and found the prisoner lying down on his left side—I saw blood on his right hand—as he got up I saw a knife projecting out of his pocket—I took it out—I saw blood on the handle—I handed it to a constable in the same state as I found it.

GEORGE ROBINSON (Police Inspector). On 15th October I was at Guy's Hospital, when Mr. Blade, the Magistrate, was there with his clerk in the ward where Arnold was—the prisoner was taken there by me, and Arnold's deposition was taken in his presence—he had the opportunity of cross-examining him—he said nothing—Arnold's deposition was read over to him, and he put his cross to it. (As the present charge against the prisoner was that of murder, and at that time Arnold being alive, and it not appearing what the charge then was against the prisoner, MR. JUSTICE STEPHEN held that the deposition of Arnold could not be read.)

REGINALD JOHN RYALL . I was house surgeon at Guy's Hospital on Sunday morning, 21st September, when Arnold was brought in, about 1.20—he had a wound on the outer side of the left thigh, near the upper part between two and three inches deep, and about lour inches long—he was in a state of extreme prostration from heamorrhage, and was in danger from that—he was unconscious, and almost pulseless—he rallied—I attended him till 25th October, when he died—in the meantime Dr. Goodheart had seen him once or twice, and was present at the post
mortem—the cause of death was pyaemia, resulting from the wound—that is a species of blood-poisoning—the wound formed an abscess on the lungs; that was a sign of the pyaemia—that is a very common result from a serious wound.
Cross-examined. I have seen the two knives produced—either of them would cause such a wound; they are equally pointed.
DR. JAMES FREDERICK GOODHEART . I am assistant physician and lecturer on pathology at Guy's—I was present at the post-mortem referred to by Mr. By all, and agree with his evidence.

p.hi: The prisoner's mother deposed to his good character.

div1.p:
GUILTY
of manslaughter. The Jury stated that there was a considerable amount of provocation. —
Five Years' Penal Servitude.
ADHOURNED TO MONDAY, DECEMBER 15TH, 1884.
